elements.content: Seven new coordination polymers based on the redox-active tetra­(4-pyridyl)-tetrathiafulvalene ligand (TTF­(py)4) and different transition-metal ions, namely, {[Cu­(hfac)2]­[TTF­(py)4]·2­(CH2Cl2)} n (1), {[Co­(acac)2]­[TTF­(py)4]0.5·(CHCl3)} n (2), {[Mn­(hfac)2]­[TTF­(py)4]0.5} n (3), {[Cu2(OAc)4]­[TTF­(py)4]0.5·1.5­(CHCl3)·0.5­(H2O)·(CH3CN)} n (4), {[Mn­(SCN)2]­[TTF­(py)4]·6­(CH2Cl2)} n (5), {[Mn­(SeCN)­Cl]­[TTF­(py)4]} n (6), and {Cu2[TTF­(py)4]2·(ClO4)2·2.5­(CH2Cl2)·1.5­(CH3CN)} n (7), were synthesized and characterized. The tetrapyridyl ligand coordinates to metal ions in a bidentate or tetradentate fashion, forming complexes 1–7 with different structures. Complex 1 exhibits a one-dimensional chain structure. Complexes 2, 3, and 4 possess similar (4,2)-connected binodal two-dimensional networks, while complexes 5 and 6 have similar (4,4)-connected binodal two-dimensional networks with two different rings. Complex 7 shows a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,4)-connected binodal PtS-type three-dimensional framework. Meanwhile, these complexes feature diverse nonclassical hydrogen bonding interactions. In addition, magnetic and solid-state electrochemical properties for typical complexes have been studied.

elements.content: Seven new coordination polymers based on the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrapyridyl ligand were synthesized and characterized. Complex 1 exhibits a one-dimensional chain structure, while complexes 2−6 show two-dimensional networks. Complex 7 has a two-fold interpenetrated PtS-type 3D framework. The results demonstrate the versatile coordination modes from the TTF­(py)4 ligand. Antiferromagnetic interaction was observed in complexes 2, 5, and 6. The coordination polymers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 showed the redox activity of the TTF moiety.

The coordination polymers 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 showed the redox activity of the TTF moiety.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed from metal ions or clusters and functionalized organic ligands have received considerable attention in recent years for their intriguing structures and their potential applications in gas storage, sensing, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism, among others. The integration of ligands with appropriate geometries and functionalities are important in directing the structure and properties of frameworks. Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF), a sulfur-rich conjugated core, can be easily and reversibly oxidized into its corresponding cationic radical (TTF• +) and dictation (TTF2+) and has been studied extensively as a component of conductive and optoelectronic materials. Many attempts have been made to derivatize TTF with functional groups that can bind to transition-metal ions. It is well-known that pyridyl groups have a strong ability to coordinate different metal ions. In this context, the association of redox-active pyridyl ligands containing the TTF core with metallic centers is an effective approach to synthesize interesting multifunctional materials. Over the past decade, monopyridine, bipyridine, and tetrapyridine organic ligands in which the pyridyl group is directly linked to the TTF moiety, and the corresponding complexes of these ligands have been reported. These types of coordination compounds containing TTF show zero-dimensional (0D) or one-dimensional (1D) crystal structures and electrochemical activity resulting from the TTF moiety.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) constructed from metal ions or clusters and functionalized organic ligands have received considerable attention in recent years for their intriguing structures and their potential applications in gas storage, sensing, catalysis, luminescence, and magnetism, among others. The integration of ligands with appropriate geometries and functionalities are important in directing the structure and properties of frameworks. Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF), a sulfur-rich conjugated core, can be easily and reversibly oxidized into its corresponding cationic radical (TTF⋅+) and dictation (TTF2+) and has been studied extensively as a component of conductive and optoelectronic materials. Many attempts have been made to derivatize TTF with functional groups that can bind to transition-metal ions. It is well-known that pyridyl groups have a strong ability to coordinate different metal ions. In this context, the association of redox-active pyridyl ligands containing the TTF core with metallic centers is an effective approach to synthesize interesting multifunctional materials. Over the past decade, monopyridine, bipyridine, and tetrapyridine organic ligands in which the pyridyl group is directly linked to the TTF moiety, and the corresponding complexes of these ligands have been reported. These types of coordination compounds containing TTF show zero-dimensional (0D) or one-dimensional (1D) crystal structures and electrochemical activity resulting from the TTF moiety.

elements.content: Recently, Therrien and Sallé et al. have successfully prepared the interesting tetrapyridyl-TTF ligand (TTF­(py)4; see ). Based on this ligand, four arene ruthenium­(II) complexes (one molecular cube and three metallaplates) have been studied. The incorporation of magnetic moment carriers such as paramagnetic ions into MOFs allows for the development of novel multifunctional materials with additional magnetic properties, including ferromagnetism or ferrimagnetism, and spin crossover effects. Of particular interest is the investigation of the structures and physical properties of polymeric metal complexes incorporating both paramagnetic transition-metal ions and the redox-active TTF­(py)4 ligand.

Based on this ligand, four arene ruthenium(II) complexes (one molecular cube and three metallaplates) have been studied. The incorporation of magnetic moment carriers such as paramagnetic ions into MOFs allows for the development of novel multifunctional materials with additional magnetic properties, including ferromagnetism or ferrimagnetism, and spin crossover effects. Of particular interest is the investigation of the structures and physical properties of polymeric metal complexes incorporating both paramagnetic transition-metal ions and the redox-active TTF(py)4 ligand.

elements.content: In this paper, six new coordination polymers based on the TTF­(py)4 ligand and different paramagnetic metal ions (Cu­(II), Co­(II) or Mn­(II)), and one coordination polymer including the diamagnetic Cu­(I) ion, have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. The experimental results indicate that the four pyridyl groups of the TTF­(py)4 ligand can partially or completely coordinate with the metal ions, giving rise to a range of coordination structures. Herein, the preparation, structural analyses, and magnetic and solid-state electrochemical properties of these complexes are described.

The experimental results indicate that the four pyridyl groups of the TTF(py)4 ligand can partially or completely coordinate with the metal ions, giving rise to a range of coordination structures. Herein, the preparation, structural analyses, and magnetic and solid-state electrochemical properties of these complexes are described.

elements.content: The crystal statistics of complexes 1, 3, 5, and 7 were collected with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), and those of complexes 2, 4, and 6 were obtained using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) on a CCD diffractometer. The cell parameters were retrieved and refined using computer software (SMART and SAINT, respectively).. The SADABS program was applied for absorption corrections. Structures were solved by direct methods using the program package SHELXL-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located in the Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic parameters. Some contribution of the electron density in compounds of 6 and 7 from the remaining solvent molecules was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON, which was determined by elemental analysis. Crystal data are summarized in . Selected bond distances and angles are given in in the Supporting Information. The crystal for 5 was seriously unstable and, thus, better crystallographic data could not be obtained.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The crystal statistics of complexes 1, 3, 5, and 7 were collected with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), and those of complexes 2, 4, and 6 were obtained using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) on a CCD diffractometer. The cell parameters were retrieved and refined using computer software (SMART and SAINT, respectively).. The SADABS program was applied for absorption corrections. Structures were solved by direct methods using the program package SHELXL-97. All the non-hydrogen atoms were located in the Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic parameters. Some contribution of the electron density in compounds of 6 and 7 from the remaining solvent molecules was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON, which was determined by elemental analysis. Crystal data are summarized in . Selected bond distances and angles are given in  in the Supporting Information. The crystal for 5 was seriously unstable and, thus, better crystallographic data could not be obtained.

Based on the TTF­(py)4 ligand, seven coordination polymers with paramagnetic transition-metal ions (Cu­(II), Co­(II), and Mn­(II)), and the diamagnetic Cu­(I) ion, were successfully obtained using similar reaction conditions. One reason for the differing structures obtained is that the four pyridyl groups of the TTF­(py)4 ligand can partially or completely coordinate the metal ions, allowing for a variety of coordination modes and resulting structures. In addition, the diverse coordination environments of the metal ions, solvent systems, and anions can also result in distinct structures, as reported in related literature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Based on the TTF(py)4 ligand, seven coordination polymers with paramagnetic transition-metal ions (Cu(II), Co(II), and Mn(II)), and the diamagnetic Cu(I) ion, were successfully obtained using similar reaction conditions. One reason for the differing structures obtained is that the four pyridyl groups of the TTF(py)4 ligand can partially or completely coordinate the metal ions, allowing for a variety of coordination modes and resulting structures. In addition, the diverse coordination environments of the metal ions, solvent systems, and anions can also result in distinct structures, as reported in related literature.

elements.content: Materials 1–7 were obtained as polymeric metal compounds in mixed-solvent systems using combinations of the TTF­(py)4 ligand and different inorganic metal salts. It is important to note that the products are not dependent on the ligand-to-metal ratio in these specific reactions; however, an increase in the metal-to-ligand ratio resulted in somewhat higher yields and higher-quality crystals. To ensure that the bulk materials were truly representative of the crystal structures, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) experiments for 1–3 and 5–7 were carried out at room temperature (see in the Supporting Information). The framework of compound 4 quickly collapses in air, and no ideal XRD spectrum was obtained. Thermogravimetric analysis experiments (see in the Supporting Information) were also conducted to determine the thermal stability of these compounds (1, 4, and 7). However, the crystals of 1, 4, and 7 are unstable and lose solvent molecules quickly in air, so the TGA data could not be used to calculate the exact number of solvent molecules.

Thermogravimetric analysis experiments (see  in the Supporting Information) were also conducted to determine the thermal stability of these compounds (1, 4, and 7). However, the crystals of 1, 4, and 7 are unstable and lose solvent molecules quickly in air, so the TGA data could not be used to calculate the exact number of solvent molecules.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 1 contains one Cu­(II) atom, two hfac anions, a TTF­(py)4 ligand, and two free CH2Cl2 molecules. As shown in a, the central Cu­(II) ion lies on the inversion center and adopts a distorted octahedral coordination environment, which is defined by four oxygen donors from two hfac anions in the equatorial plane and two pyridyl nitrogen donors from two ligands. The Cu–O bonds range from 2.078(4) Å to 2.155(4) Å. The pyridyl nitrogen atoms of the ligand occupy the axial positions with the shortest Cu1–N2 bond length of 2.013(4) Å. The TTF backbone exhibits a Z-like configuration with a dihedral angle of 9.4° folding at S1–S2. The central CC bond length of the TTF core is 1.334(10) Å. The bond lengths and angles of TTF­(py)4 are similar to those reported for the neutral unit, indicating that the TTF­(py)4 ligand can be still be regarded as charge-neutral. No obvious intermolecular π···π and shorter S···S interactions can be observed in the packing diagram. The TTF­(py)4 ligand acts as 2-connected node to link Cu­(hfac)2 units into a 1D chain (b).

elements.content: These compounds show similar two-dimensional (2D) network structures formed by the TTF­(4-py)4 ligand with Co­(acac)2, Mn­(hfac)2, and Cu2(OAc)4, respectively. Among them, the TTF­(py)4 ligand acts as a 4-connected node to link the M­(II) units into 2D networks.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 2, 3, and 4 

These compounds show similar two-dimensional (2D) network structures formed by the TTF(4-py)4 ligand with Co(acac)2, Mn(hfac)2, and Cu2(OAc)4, respectively. Among them, the TTF(py)4 ligand acts as a 4-connected node to link the M(II) units into 2D networks.

elements.content: For 2, the asymmetric unit consists of two Co ions, one TTF­(py)4 ligand, four acac anions, and two CHCl3 molecules. As shown in a, each Co­(II) center adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, which consists of four O atoms from two bidentate acac anions in the equatorial plane and two N atoms from two TTF­(py)4 ligands in apical positions. The Co–O bond lengths range from 2.030 Å to 2.040 Å. The Co1–N2 and Co2–N1 bond lengths are 2.221(3) Å and 2.188(3) Å, respectively. In a similar fashion to 1, the TTF backbone shows a Z-like configuration with a dihedral angle of 9.6° folding at S1–S2. The central CC bond of the TTF core is 1.329(7) Å in length, confirming that the TTF moiety is in its neutral state. All Co­(II) centers are connected to each other by the TTF­(py)4 ligands to form a (4,2)-connected binodal 2D network, which consists of a rhombus grid in which the CHCl3 molecules are located (b). The window has a dimension of 20.7 Å × 24.9 Å. These 2D nets are planar, and stack together to give a three-dimensional (3D) framework through nonclassical hydrogen bonds C(2)–H(2)···O(4) (H···O distance, 2.51 Å) and C(17)–H­(17A)···O(1) (H···O distance, 2.53 Å) (c). Viewing the structure along the crystallographic a axis, rhombus-like channels are observed (d).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment of the Co­(II) ion in 2 (50% probability displacement ellipsoids); (b) two-dimensional (2D) layer in 2; (c) the nonclassical hydrogen bonds between the adjacent layers; and (d) view of crystal packing in 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination environment of the Co(II) ion in 2 (50% probability displacement ellipsoids); (b) two-dimensional (2D) layer in 2; (c) the nonclassical hydrogen bonds between the adjacent layers; and (d) view of crystal packing in 2.

elements.content: To investigate the effect of the identity of the metal ions on the formation of the coordination polymers, compound 3 was prepared using the same reaction conditions as those employed for 1, but using Mn­(hfac)2·2H2O instead of Cu­(hfac)2·2H2O. In a fashion similar to that used for the Cu­(II) center in 1, the Mn­(II) ions also adopt a distorted octahedral coordination sphere (a). The TTF backbone shows a Z-like configuration with a dihedral angle of 5.2° folding at S1–S2, which is smaller than those in 1 and 2. The central CC bond length of the TTF core is 1.357(4) Å, which is comparable to those found in 1 and 2. However, for complex 3, the TTF­(py)4 ligand acts as a tetradentate ligand for the Mn­(II) ions and leads to the formation of a 2D network instead of the 1D chain structure of 1 (b). The windows have a similar dimension to that in 2 (20.0 Å × 26.1 Å). These 2D nets are also planar, and they are stacked exactly together to give a 3D framework through nonclassical hydrogen bonds C(7)–H(7)···O(2) (H···O distance, 2.38 Å). Viewing the structure along the a-axis, rhombus-like channels are also found; however, there are no guest solvent molecules in the channels (see in the Supporting Information).

elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Coordination environment of the Mn(II) ion in 3 (50% probability displacement ellipsoids); (b) 2D layer in 3.

elements.content: For compound 4, as shown in a, the two Cu centers adopt a distorted square-based pyramidal coordination environment formed by four carboxyl oxygen atoms from four different carboxylate groups in the basal planes and one N atom from the TTF­(py)4 ligand in apical positions. The structure of neutral TTF also shows a Z-like conformation. The dihedral angle folding at S1–S2 is 3.6°, smaller than those of 1–3. The central CC bond length of the TTF unit is 1.348(8) Å, which is close to that 3. The TTF­(py)4 ligands act as a 4-connected node to link four metal ions, whereas the OAc anions adopt a 2-connected bridging mode connecting two metal ions. In this way, each TTF­(py)4 ligand is bound to four [Cu2(OAc)4] units to yield a 2D network with dinuclear Cu cores separated by 2.600(11) Å, which is comparable to those found in the related complex, [(DMT-TTF–py)2Cu2(OAc)2]·4C6H6 (2.620 Å). In a fashion similar to that for compounds 2 and 3, the 2D sheet consists of a rhombus ring ( in the Supporting Information), whose dimensions are 20.7 Å × 31.3 Å, which are larger than those of 2 and 3. The difference in the dimensions is predominantly due to the Cu2(OAc)4 moiety. Through nonclassical hydrogen bonds (C(4)–H(4)···S(2), H···S distance, 2.87 Å), these 2D nets are further connected to yield the 3D framework (). Viewing the structure along the a-axis, rhombus channels are found, in which CHCl3, H2O, and CH3CN molecules are located (see b).

elements.content: In complex 5, there is only one Mn­(II) center in the asymmetric unit, and the Mn atom lies in a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, formed by four N atoms from four TTF­(py)4 ligands in the equatorial plane and two N atoms from two SCN– anions in the axial positions (a). Compared to 3, the Mn­(II)–Npyridyl bond length (2.304 Å) is significantly elongated. The neutral TTF units are almost coplanar with a dihedral angle of 0.9° folding at S1–S2. The central CC bond length of the TTF units is 1.350(3) Å, which is similar to that found in 3 and 4. As indicated in b, the TTF­(py)4 ligand links the inorganic Mn­(SCN)2 units into a (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network, which are parallel to the crystallographic ab plane and consist of two different individual rings. The larger one is a 30-membered elliptical macrocycle whose approximate (crystallographic) dimensions are 16.51 Å × 9.72 Å. The smaller one is a 22-membered dimeric unit with dimensions of 10.16 Å × 9.73 Å. These 2D nets are planar and stack together along the crystallographic c-axis in an −ABAB– stacking sequence (see c). The CH2Cl2 molecules are located between the interlayer spaces. Viewing the structure along the crystallographic c-axis, rhombus channels are found and the dimensions are much smaller than that found in 2, 3, and 4, because of the different stacking sequence. Compared to 3, the difference in the structure and stacking mode indicates the remarkable influence that the different anion and solvent system imparts to the structure.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 5 and 6 

In complex 5, there is only one Mn(II) center in the asymmetric unit, and the Mn atom lies in a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, formed by four N atoms from four TTF(py)4 ligands in the equatorial plane and two N atoms from two SCN- anions in the axial positions (a). Compared to 3, the Mn(II)-Npyridyl bond length (2.304 Å) is significantly elongated. The neutral TTF units are almost coplanar with a dihedral angle of 0.9° folding at S1-S2. The central CC bond length of the TTF units is 1.350(3) Å, which is similar to that found in 3 and 4. As indicated in b, the TTF(py)4 ligand links the inorganic Mn(SCN)2 units into a (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network, which are parallel to the crystallographic ab plane and consist of two different individual rings. The larger one is a 30-membered elliptical macrocycle whose approximate (crystallographic) dimensions are 16.51 Å × 9.72 Å. The smaller one is a 22-membered dimeric unit with dimensions of 10.16 Å × 9.73 Å. These 2D nets are planar and stack together along the crystallographic c-axis in an -ABAB- stacking sequence (see c). The CH2Cl2 molecules are located between the interlayer spaces. Viewing the structure along the crystallographic c-axis, rhombus channels are found and the dimensions are much smaller than that found in 2, 3, and 4, because of the different stacking sequence. Compared to 3, the difference in the structure and stacking mode indicates the remarkable influence that the different anion and solvent system imparts to the structure.

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment for Mn­(II) ion in 5 (30% probability displacement ellipsoids); (b) 2D layer in 5; and (c) view of crystal packing in 5. CH2Cl2 molecules (shown as space-filling) between the layers.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Coordination environment for Mn(II) ion in 5 (30% probability displacement ellipsoids); (b) 2D layer in 5; and (c) view of crystal packing in 5. CH2Cl2 molecules (shown as space-filling) between the layers.

elements.content: The use of KSeCN for the preparation of complex 6, instead of KSCN in 5, allowed an investigation into the effect of the anion on the coordination polymer. Compared to 5, only one Cl– anion is substituted by SeCN– in 6. The central CC bond length of the TTF core is 1.383(14) Å, which is longer than those found in 1–5. The coordination interaction between the TTF­(py)4 ligand and the Mn­(II) ions leads to a 2D network, which is similar to that of 5 (see a). The TTF moiety adopts a U-like configuration with a dihedral angle of 22.8° folding at S1–S2, and a dihedral angle of 15.7° folding at S3–S4. Thus, this 2D net is undulating and stacks together along the crystallographic b-axis in an −ABAB– stacking sequence (b). However, no significant intermolecular π···π and S···S contacts (<3.60 Å) were found in 6. The shortest S···S distance between two neighboring TTF cores is 3.872(4) Å. The difference between compounds 5 with 6 may result from different coordination behaviors of the anion.

elements.content: The counteranions in 1–6 are all coordinated to the metal ions. The more weakly coordinating ClO4 – anion was used, instead of the strongly coordinating anions, to investigate the effect on the structure of the coordination polymer. As shown in a, the Cu­(I) centers adopt a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, which consists of four Npyridyl donors from four TTF­(py)4 ligands. The weakly coordinating ClO4 – anions do not involve the Cu­(I) coordination sphere. In a similar fashion to 6, the structure of one neutral TTF moiety shows a U-like configuration with a dihedral angle of 14.5° folding at S1–S2, and a dihedral angle of 13.8° folding at S3–S4, which is smaller than that in 6. However, the other two TTF moieties adopt a Z-like conformation with a dihedral angle of 10.7° folding at S5–S6, and a dihedral angle of 12.3° folding at S7–S8. The central CC bond length of the TTF cores is 1.343(8) Å for C12–C13, 1.346(10) Å for C32–C32A Å, and 1.345(10) Å for C51–C51A. Four Cu­(I) ions are linked by six TTF­(py)4 ligands into a tetranuclear {Cu4[TTF­(py)4]6} cagelike sub-building block, in which the shortest Cu­(I)···Cu­(I) distance is 15.56(1) Å (b). These cagelike sub-building blocks are bound together by TTF­(py)4 ligands into a novel 3D net (c). When viewed down the crystallographic b-axis, two types of channelsmarked as “A” (pore dimensions of 16.3 Å × 24.3 Å) and “B” (pore dimensions of 8.9 Å × 10.0 Å) (c)are found. Two such nets interpenetrate each other to form a 2-fold interpenetrating framework (d). Better insight into this framework can be achieved through an analysis of the topology. The structure can be regarded as a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,4)-connected binodal PtS-type 3D framework with the Schläfli symbol of (42, 84) (see d, as well as in the Supporting Information). The experimental results show that the gas absorption properties of this porous framework are not special, which is comparable to those found in the similar framework, [Cd­(bipy) (bdc)] and [Zn­(bdc)-(4,4′-bipy)0.5] (see in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The coordination modes and conformations of the TTF­(py)4 ligand in complexes 1–7 are illustrated in . In the structure of 1, the ligand acts as a bidentate spacer. In complexes 2–7, the ligand exhibits a tetradentate bridging mode. The TTF­(py)4 ligand is not coplanar in these compounds. The conformations of the TTF backbone are similar in compounds 1–5 and 7B, exhibiting a Z-like configuration. The conformations of the TTF backbone in compounds 6 and 7A are U-like. The central CC bond lengths of the neutral TTF units range from 1.329(7) Å to 1.385(14) Å (see ). The dihedral angle between two adjacent pyridyl rings of the TTF­(py)4 ligand in 1–7 is in the range of 50.9°–80.4°. The above geometrical data are important for the construction of 1D–3D coordination polymers with channels.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination Modes and Conformations of the Tetra(4-pyridyl)TTF Ligand

The coordination modes and conformations of the TTF(py)4 ligand in complexes 1-7 are illustrated in . In the structure of 1, the ligand acts as a bidentate spacer. In complexes 2-7, the ligand exhibits a tetradentate bridging mode. The TTF(py)4 ligand is not coplanar in these compounds. The conformations of the TTF backbone are similar in compounds 1-5 and 7B, exhibiting a Z-like configuration. The conformations of the TTF backbone in compounds 6 and 7A are U-like. The central CC bond lengths of the neutral TTF units range from 1.329(7) Å to 1.385(14) Å (see ). The dihedral angle between two adjacent pyridyl rings of the TTF(py)4 ligand in 1-7 is in the range of 50.9°-80.4°. The above geometrical data are important for the construction of 1D-3D coordination polymers with channels.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on polycrystalline samples of compounds 2, 5, and 6 using a SQUID magnetometer at temperatures ranging from 2 K to 300 K in a magnetic field of 1000 Oe.

elements.content: As shown in , the main observation from the χM T vs T curves for compounds 2, 5, and 6 is that they are antiferromagnetic. At 300 K, the χM T value is 3.51 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, which is lower than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 (g = 2.0) expected for two isolated high-spin CoII centers (S = 3/2). The χM T value slowly decreases upon cooling and reaches 3.16 cm3 K mol–1 at 100 K, and then steeply decreases to 1.98 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. At 300 K, the χM T value is 4.65 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 4.86 cm3 K mol–1 for 6, which is slightly higher than that expected for the spin-only value of the Mn­(II) ion (4.376 cm3 K mol–1 with g = 2.0). The χM T value decreases gradually upon cooling, and reaches a value of 4.63 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 4.65 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 100 K; it then rapidly decreases to 3.65 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 3.83 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 2 K. The negative θ values for these compounds obtained by the Curie–Weiss equation (−6.634 K for 2, – 1.190 K for 5, and −4.427 K for 6) are also indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: Many coordination complexes involving TTF redox active ligands have been electrochemically characterized, but the study of redox properties of higher-dimensionality coordination complexes with TTF ligands is limited by their insolubility. In this work, solution-state electrochemistry of the TTF­(py)4 ligand and solid-state cyclic voltammetry (CV) of 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 were performed to investigate the redox properties. Here, the redox properties of TTF­(py)4 and 6 are discussed, while the redox properties and CVs of 1, 2, 3, and 5 are provided in in the Supporting Information. The electrochemical data are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Electrochemistry

Many coordination complexes involving TTF redox active ligands have been electrochemically characterized, but the study of redox properties of higher-dimensionality coordination complexes with TTF ligands is limited by their insolubility. In this work, solution-state electrochemistry of the TTF(py)4 ligand and solid-state cyclic voltammetry (CV) of 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 were performed to investigate the redox properties. Here, the redox properties of TTF(py)4 and 6 are discussed, while the redox properties and CVs of 1, 2, 3, and 5 are provided in  in the Supporting Information. The electrochemical data are listed in .

elements.content:
Redox Potentials of TTF­(py)<sub>4</sub> and Complexes <bold>1</bold>, <bold>2</bold>, <bold>3</bold>, <bold>5</bold>, and <bold>6</bold> Redox Potentials (V) vs Fc/Fc+ redox couple TTF(py)4 1 2 3 5 6 TTF/TTF• + 0.18 0.68 –0.13 0.43 0.30 0.22 TTF• +/TTF2+ 0.36 1.09 0.23 0.88 0.56 0.61 Red1 –1.79 –2.08 –0.91 –2.03 –1.87 –1.91 Red2 –2.09 Red3 –2.23 Red4 –2.30 Co2+/3+ 0.64 Co2+/1+ –1.38 Cu2+/1+ –1.80 Mn2+/3+ 0.21, −0.36

Reported values are E onset potentials of irreversible processes.

Solution-state electrochemistry was performed on TTF­(py)4 in 0.1 M TBAPF6/DMF electrolyte (). At a scan rate of 100 mV/s, TTF­(py)4 demonstrates good cyclability over the potential window of −2.70 V to 1.09 V vs Fc/Fc+. The anodic region is dominated by two reversible oxidation waves at E 1/2 = 0.18 and 0.36 V, because of the oxidation of neutral TTF to its radical cation and dication states, respectively. The cathodic region shows four reversible reduction waves, at E 1/2 = −1.79, – 2.09, – 2.23 (E onset potential; overlap with the peak at −2.30 V has obscured the presence of a potential reverse peak) and −2.30 V. These four processes may be assigned to the four-electron reduction of the four pyridyl rings, where each one-electron reduction results in delocalization over the entire molecule, making the subsequent reductions progressively more difficult. This ultimately suggests that there is considerable electron delocalization between the pyridyl rings, which is mediated by the TTF core.

elements.clean_text: 9  Solution-state cyclic voltammograms of TTF(py)4 (over three repeat cycles at 100 mV/s).

elements.content: The solid-state cyclic voltammograms of 6 () show two irreversible oxidation peaks at onset potentials of 0.22 and 0.61 V, corresponding well with the TTF/TTF• + and TTF• +/TTF2+ redox couples, respectively. Upon successive cycling of the potential, these two processes are no longer observed, which is consistent with their irreversibility. Two irreversible peaks are also observed in the forward and reverse scans at onset potentials of 0.21 and −0.36 V vs Fc/Fc+, and may correspond to the oxidation, and subsequent reduction, of Mn2+/3+. The large peak separation can be attributed to the hindered nature of counterion diffusion through the sheets of the framework. A quasi-reversible reduction wave observed at −1.91 V is ascribed to the reduction of the pyridyl rings. Beyond the scanned cathodic potential limit, a sharp spike in current associated with complete reduction of the pyridyl rings resulted in degradation of the framework material.

elements.content: A series of new coordination polymers based on the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene–tetrapyridyl ligand were synthesized and structurally characterized. The tetrapyridyl ligand was coordinated to metal ions in a bidentate or tetradentate fashion, leading to the formation of versatile structures for the coordination polymers. Complex 1 exhibited a one-dimensional chain structure, while complexes 2, 3, and 4 exhibited (4,2)-connected binodal two-dimensional (2D) network stacking in an −AA– sequence. Complexes 5 and 6 possess a similar (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network stacking in an −ABAB– sequence. Meanwhile, complex 7 was characterized as a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,4)-connected binodal PtS-type three-dimensional (3D) framework. Complexes 2, 5, and 6 show antiferromagnetic interactions between magnetic centers. The electrochemical studies on five compounds showed that the redox activity of the TTF moiety was retained in the new coordination polymers. The results suggest that the incorporation of redox-active ligands into coordination frameworks can be useful for the development of interesting redox-active materials. Further investigations on TTF­(py)4 compounds with new structures and multifunctional properties are currently underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of new coordination polymers based on the redox-active tetrathiafulvalene-tetrapyridyl ligand were synthesized and structurally characterized. The tetrapyridyl ligand was coordinated to metal ions in a bidentate or tetradentate fashion, leading to the formation of versatile structures for the coordination polymers. Complex 1 exhibited a one-dimensional chain structure, while complexes 2, 3, and 4 exhibited (4,2)-connected binodal two-dimensional (2D) network stacking in an -AA- sequence. Complexes 5 and 6 possess a similar (4,4)-connected binodal 2D network stacking in an -ABAB- sequence. Meanwhile, complex 7 was characterized as a 2-fold interpenetrated (4,4)-connected binodal PtS-type three-dimensional (3D) framework. Complexes 2, 5, and 6 show antiferromagnetic interactions between magnetic centers. The electrochemical studies on five compounds showed that the redox activity of the TTF moiety was retained in the new coordination polymers. The results suggest that the incorporation of redox-active ligands into coordination frameworks can be useful for the development of interesting redox-active materials. Further investigations on TTF(py)4 compounds with new structures and multifunctional properties are currently underway in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content: As shown in , the main observation from the χM T vs T curves for compounds 2, 5, and 6 is that they are antiferromagnetic. At 300 K, the χM T value is 3.51 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, which is lower than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 (g = 2.0) expected for two isolated high-spin CoII centers (S = 3/2). The χM T value slowly decreases upon cooling and reaches 3.16 cm3 K mol–1 at 100 K, and then steeply decreases to 1.98 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. At 300 K, the χM T value is 4.65 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 4.86 cm3 K mol–1 for 6, which is slightly higher than that expected for the spin-only value of the Mn­(II) ion (4.376 cm3 K mol–1 with g = 2.0). The χM T value decreases gradually upon cooling, and reaches a value of 4.63 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 4.65 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 100 K; it then rapidly decreases to 3.65 cm3 K mol–1 for 5 and 3.83 cm3 K mol–1 for 6 at 2 K. The negative θ values for these compounds obtained by the Curie–Weiss equation (−6.634 K for 2, – 1.190 K for 5, and −4.427 K for 6) are also indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions.
cln_elements.clean_text: As shown in , the main observation from the χM T vs T curves for compounds 2, 5, and 6 is that they are antiferromagnetic. At 300 K, the χM T value is 3.51 cm3 K mol-1 for 2, which is lower than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol-1 (g = 2.0) expected for two isolated high-spin CoII centers (S = 3/2). The χM T value slowly decreases upon cooling and reaches 3.16 cm3 K mol-1 at 100 K, and then steeply decreases to 1.98 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. At 300 K, the χM T value is 4.65 cm3 K mol-1 for 5 and 4.86 cm3 K mol-1 for 6, which is slightly higher than that expected for the spin-only value of the Mn(II) ion (4.376 cm3 K mol-1 with g = 2.0). The χM T value decreases gradually upon cooling, and reaches a value of 4.63 cm3 K mol-1 for 5 and 4.65 cm3 K mol-1 for 6 at 100 K; it then rapidly decreases to 3.65 cm3 K mol-1 for 5 and 3.83 cm3 K mol-1 for 6 at 2 K. The negative θ values for these compounds obtained by the Curie-Weiss equation (-6.634 K for 2, - 1.190 K for 5, and -4.427 K for 6) are also indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions.
